cab.content: SECRET, MINISTRY OF FOOD.jr^^pfieport for Week ending Wednesday, January 8, 1919.PART I.-ACTION TAKEN. Inter-Allied Food Control.1 mmhhhmi The Associated Governments have decided to establish a Supreme Council, consisting of two representatives of France, Italy, the United States, and Great Britain, to deal with the questions of food, finance, and shipping resources in relation to the revictualling and supply of Liberated and Enemy Territory, and to co-ordinate such supplies with supplies for Allied and Neutral countries. At the request of the War Cabinet, Lord Reading and Sir John Beale will, for the time being, represent His Majesty's Government on this Council. Certain emergency measures have already been taken to provide relief where needs are acute. In this way assistance is being rendered to Serbia and Rumania. The Inter-Allied Commission (upon which Sir William Beveridge is the British Representative) inquiring into the food needs of German-Austria, has met represen- tatives of Vienna and of the German-Austrian territories at Berne. In view of the serious food situation in these territories, interim arrangements are being made for the supply of a certain quantity of foodstuffs, and some supplies have already been sent to Vienna. The Food Gouncil. Mr. Clynes presided over meetings of the Council on Thursday, January 2nd, and Tuesday, January 7th. The Council have decided that no fresh ration books shall be issued for the period May to November. As regards meat and sugar it was agreed that after the present books expire at the beginning of May retailers should be rationed, and the customers tied to particular retailers ; if necessary the spare leaf in the present book could be used. It was agreed that butter and margarine should be taken off the coupon as soon as possible but that retailers would continue to be rationed and the customer entitled to a certain maintenance. The ration is to be increased from January 12th from five ounces to six ounces, in the proportion of five ounces of margarine and one ounce of butter. A similar increase will also be made in the kosher margarine ration. Sir A. Anderson reported that the United States Government proposed to free all exportable food products dealt with by the Meat and Fats Executive, with the exception of dairy produce. The view of the Council was that, as regards hog products, private importation from the United States should be permitted as soon as importers were willing to take over the stocks of the Ministry of Food at cost price. The Council assented to the export of surplus stocks of pickled horseflesh to Belgium. A proposal for lowering the retail price of condensed milk by lfi. per tin was approved. It was agreed that the Imports Board should be authorised to import 32,000 cases of condensed milk from New Zealand during the present cereal year. The Council approved a proposal put forward by Lord Bledisloe (a) for making at the earliest possible date an allowance of sugar to philanthropic buffets, &c, established for the benefit of members of His Majesty's Forces, and (b) for increasing the allowance to all catering establishments, and at the same date removing the prohibition on the use of sugar for sweetening beverages. A memorandum by Lord Bledisloe on the resumption of the export trade in confectionery was also considered. It was agreed that a yearly export of confectionery, &c, up to about 25 per cent, of the 1913 exports should be allowed.A , The Food Controller has decided that an announcement should be made at once that it is not intended to alter the existing prices of milk up to the end of April. It was agreed that a decision on the question of summer prices could not be given at present, but that the Board of Agriculture should be consulted before a decision was arrived at. ;' A (33)7191-1 Pk9 145 1/19 B k S A The question of fixing the price of salt was discussed. It was reported thatmanufacturers were making profits in excess of the scale suggested by the CostingsDepartment, but only 7 per cent, of the total output was for domestic use. It wasagreed that it was not worth while talcing action to control prices at the present stage in view of the fact that ordinary commercial conditions would probably tend to lower prices. The Food Controller has decided that a further memorandum should be sent tothe Cabinet pressing for a decision on the suggested increase in the output of beer,and submitting the scales of prices. It was agreed that the Prices Order need notapply to Ireland. A letter from the Ministry of Munitions was considered, recommending thatRegulation 30d of the Defence of the Realm Regulations should be suspended, thuspermitting the use of grain by distilleries for the production of spirit. The Councilagreed that Regulation 30n should be suspended and that the resumption of distillingshould be. permitted generally. The Imports Board.-The question of the importation of bacon and hams fromthe United States and Canada has been further considered by the Board. It was reported that for the two weeks ending December 28th shipments hadaveraged 16,000 tons per week. In view of the extreme difficulty of handling morethan 12,000 tons per week here, the Board agreed that the Ministry of shipping should be requested to cable to their shipping agents at New York, stating thatshipments must on no account exceed 12,000 tons from the United States and canadian any one week, and that the excess shipments of 8,000 tons during the period endingDecember 28th must be adjusted by reduced shipments spread over the next three or four weeks. A cable in similar terms has. been sent to the Allied Provisions ExportCommission. A letter from the Danish Bacon Company was considered, suggesting thatarrangements should be made for the. supply of maize from, the Argentine to Denmark,in order that the export trade in Danish bacon may be restarted. The Board agreedthat they had no,objection to the supply of maize from the Argentine to Denmark. . The following contracts have been arranged for forward purchases : (a). Butler. This season's exportable surplus from South Africa and the Argentine till March 1919. In addition, Treasury sanction has been ' asked for the purchase of the exportable surplus from the Argentine for '.. ; the. period from April 1919 till June .1920. The exportable surplus of /butter for the seasons 1919 to August 1920 from Australia and New ., Zealand has also been contracted for.: - (k) Cheese. Contracts have been arranged for the purchase of the exportable surplus of cheese from Australia and New Zealand till May 1920, and from Canada till December 1919. (c) Tea.--(!)() per cent, of the Indian crop and 50 per cent, of the Ceylon crop . are being purchased, the total amount being 156,000 tons, value approximately 14,500,00OL The contract finishes on May 1st, 1919. It is probable that shipment will be completed by the end of March, the . amount still remaining to be shipped being 42.000 tons, (a) Cotton Seed. Contracts have been arranged for the Egyptian exportable r; ,.. \ surplus of August 1919, quantity 25,000 tons, value 2,250,000?, , The Consumers Council. The Council met on January 8th. After consideringvarious questions connected with the National Kitchens Movement and the de-rationing of jam and margarine the Council passed to the Report of the Legalisation of Improve-ments Sub-Committee. Referring to the question of the State retaining the sole rightto import essential foodstuffs the report says : The Sub-Committee do not profess to have examined this subject in all its bearings. Upon certain aspects of the subject they have, however, come to definite conclusions. First, a monopoly of State purchase of imported foodstuffs 1 would, in their opinion, be a powerful weapon not only against a foreign trust but also against a shipping ring. Second, in times of fluctuating prices, State purchase would secure the importation, of articles when a private trader would be loth to undertake the risks involved. Third, when the article is scarce or there. is. even a small excess of demand over supply or there is hot, for any reason, effective competition between dealers, prices are apt to rise to an inordinately high level a level out of all proportion to the amount of the deficiency. Our experience is that where there is any shortage, control of prices without control of distribution is of little, if of any, use, and that the best way to achieve effective distribution is for the State to have the right to exercise control by reason of its ownership of the articles controlled. Upon this head the Sub-Committee have passed the following resolution : That the Government should continue to purchase and import essential foodstuffs from overseas and should take all necessary steps through the control of imported foodstuffs to maintain supplies and control prices. With reference to the question of the removal of internal control the Sub-Com-mittee passed the following resolutions : (a) That coupon restrictions and other restrictions limiting consumption should not be retained after it becomes reasonably certain, having regard to the state of supplies, that such restrictions can be abolished without fear of having to re-impose them. (b) That registration of customers should continue for the present under arrange- ments whereby, at short intervals, the public have the unrestricted right to change their registration either generally or as to any particular . rationed article. (c) That registration of customers should not be abandoned until supplies are fully sufficient. (d) It is desirable that the retail prices of all essential foodstuffs should be fixed so long as there is any risk of scarcity and while present conditions exist, and that prices should also be fixed for such foodstuffs as are from time to time being imported by the State. The Report was adopted by the Council. SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION. Dried Fruits. The s.s. " Chiverstone " has sailed from Greece with 1,500 tonsof currants on board. The Ministry of Shipping are arranging to lift a further 15,000tons. The first steamer carrying 5,498 tons of dates has sailed, and boats are beingloaded with further quantities. Two hundred and fifty tons of dried fruit of various-descriptions have arrived from Australia. The whole of the Ministry's purchase of Californian fruits, amountingto 20,000 tons, has been despatched from the contractors, and should be available for distribution at the end of February. Meat. With a steady diminution in the supply of live stock, which is likely tobecome even more marked in the course of the next month or two, a greater measureof dependence has to be placed upon the supplies of imported meat, and the principalquestion occupying attention at the moment is the fair distribution of the limitedsupplies of home-killed meat. With this in view, the trade in many areas is beingfurnished with nothing but home-killed meat for a given period, this being followedby another given period in which only imported meat is supplied. In this, way theretailers are precluded from showing any preference to their customers, and thepossibility of one retailer having home-killed meat and his neighbour nothing hutimported meat is avoided. In view of the fact that the public are shortly to have anopportunity of transferring their registrations, if they desire to do so, it becomes amatter of importance that no retailer should occupy, a preferential, position in respectof his supplies. The only drawback to the adoption of these methods throughout thecountry lies in the fact that the shortage of labour in the stores and on the railwaysmight make it impossible to deal with the quantities of meat required under thissystem. ,,: Some few complaints are being received regarding the quality of the meatimported from North America. While it is not suggested that these complaints areunfounded, it can be stated with assurance that the quality of the meat is superior to that which gave rise to such serious trouble last summer. There is no doubt that-certain sections are becoming increasingly impatient of control and regard control as unnecessary since the signing of the Armistice. Efforts have already been made todispel this very shortsighted view. - . - ^ The losses incurred on the grading of: cattle still give rise to occasional trouble.This has been particularly marked at Derby where the butchers closed their shops and refused to take their allocation. Investigation showed that there was very littleground for complaint on the basis of the aggregate result, and the trouble has nowbeen settled. In other towns, in places such as North Wales and Cornwall, butchershave absolutely declined to handle frozen meat, but here also it is confidently expectedthat the trouble will disappear when it is realised that there is no possibility of gettingsupplies of any other description. A temporary strike at Birkenhead stopped supplies of Irish cattle through that quarter, but a satisfactory settlement has now been reached, and trade has been resumed through its normal channels. Potatoes. The position with regard to potatoes varies very much in the different areas. In Scotland it is reported that a serious difficulty is being experienced atpresent in the disposal of surplus supplies, and that unless a more ready sale isfound by transmission to England, there will be a considerable reduction in acreagenext season. It is estimated that the surplus amounts to 20,000 tons, after allowing350,000 tons to meet seed requirements. Disease in the crop is general, throughout thecountry, and is causing anxiety in some areas, more particularly in the North-eastern and South Midland Divisions, and in Lincolnshire. In the Northern Division, on theother hand, the crop is said to be keeping well on the whole. In the South-WesternDivision the crop is reported to be abundant, but not keeping well. Some idea of the difficulties caused by the prevalence of disease may be formed from the following report from the North-Eastern Division : " In the week commencing 13th December 47 waggons, of 5 tons each, "were refused from the North Riding, and in tho same period 17 waggons were refused from the East Riding, on account of disease and canker; this makes a total of 320 tons of indented potatoes refused within one week from two surplus zones." Tea. A public sale of Government tea, for export only, was held yesterday.11,301 packages were catalogued, out of which number 10,000 were sold in the saleroom at prices very much in advance of the minimum limits fixed by the Ministry.The residue was taken out of the sale at prices slightly below the limits fixed, and itis expected that this will be sold shortly at the prices fixed. A further sale will beheld on January 20th, when a similar amount of tea will be put up for auction. Orders under Defence of the Realm Regulations. The Milk (Local Distribution) Order, 1918, dated" 19th December 1918, authorisesFood Committees to control the local distribution and consumption of milk, and togrant priority to consumers. The Order came into force on 1st January. Enforcement of Orders. The total number of prosecutions recorded in the fortnight ending December 28th1918, is 922, of which 845 resulted in convictions. Sentence of imprisonment without option was inflicted in two cases, both ofwhich were under the Rationing Order. At Ley ton a woman was sentenced to threemonths' imprisonment for having made a false statement when filling -up an Appli-cation Form for a Ration Book. At South Birkenhead a woman was sentenced to one month's imprisonment for securing, and making use of, nine Ration Books, her familyconsisting of only four persons. A local meat shortage was caused at Bromley by the negligence of a butcher,who omitted to send in the required fortnightly returns for three fortnights in succession, and also to forward coupons on the specified dates. The result was thatmeat required, amounting to 2,341 lbs., was unable to be taken into account in thereturn made by the Food Committee to the Ministry, and the local supply was thuscurtailed. Defendant was fined 10L and 21. 2s. costs. Total Imports for first 18 weeks of Cereal Year compared with corresponding period in 1917. 1918. Increase or Decrease on 1917. -- 1918. Sugar -Tea -Coffee -Cocoa - Tons. 177,900 45,300 16,300 37,000 50,000 370,200 76,400 4,500 32,800 Tons. 4 93,800 4 41,900 4 3,300 - 18,400 - 12,800 4 16,100 - 123,300 4 35,400 4 2,500 4 26,900 4 HI 4 1,216 4 25 - 100 - 26 4 47 - 25 4 86 4 128 4 457 1,917,300 4 833,300 4 77 34,500 402,800 213,000 - 129,500 - 215,600 + 4,400 - 79 - 35 f] 2 CONSUMPTION. Meat. The English markets for live stock were closed for the greater part ofthe week ended 28th December and the supplies of live stock in Great Britainrepresented only 3,500 tons, which were supplemented by 400 tons of home-grownmeat from, cold stores. In addition, 3,600 tons of imported refrigerated meat were released, making a total supply of 7,500 tons. This small supply has to be taken inconjunction with the high figures for the preceding two weeks. The average weeklysupply for the four weeks ended 28th December is thus, estimated at 21,600 tons forGreat Britain, of which 18,700 tons were available against the ration. With a doubleration for Christmas week the average ration allowance was 19,000- tons for the four weeks. It therefore appears that the public did not take up the whole of the largerration to which they were entitled. Fish. The supplies of fish during the week ended 28th December were small.The quantity received at Billingsgate and other large inland markets, which had been steadily maintained at 3,600 tons per week in the first three weeks of December, fell to 1,600 tons in the fourth week. The net supplies at Billingsgate were 33 per cent.less than those for the corresponding week last year. The shortage appears to be dueto an extended Christmas holiday in the fishing industry. Table B (1).-The quantities of foodstuffs passing into consumption in theUnited Kingdom in the four weeks ended December 28th show a general reduction.This is due to the extremely low quantities issued in Christmas week. The extraration of sugar is reflected partly in the higher issues for the periods ended14th and 21st December, the remainder of the requirements having been met fromaccumulated stocks in the hands of retailers. Provisions. The returns from multiple shops and co-operative societies for - thefour weeks ended 21st December show a rise in the retail sales of eggs (26 per cent.), A 7191-1 B PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. Imports. Imports for the week ended 4th January (251,800 tons) were well above theaverage. This was partly due to the inclusion of some of the imports which actuallyarrived in the Christinas week and partly to exceptionally large imports of wheat andHour (186,600 tons as equivalent grain) which were greater than those recorded inany week since July 1917. Sugar imports (1.9,200 tons) improved but were not sufficient to meet the ration requirements. There were good imports of bacon(21,300 tons), and meat (13,400 tons), and again large imports of cocoa (3,800 tons).Imports of cereals, other than wheat, were low and no rice arrived. There were againgood imports of oranges (11,200 tons) and apples (3,700 tons), and a greatly improvedimport of bananas (1,900 tons). The total imports for the first 18 weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and 1918-19are compared in the following table : lard (21 per cent.), bacon (10 per cent.), and butter (8 per cent.), arid a fall in the sales of cheese (17 per cent.), compared with the preceding four weeks. The increasein the sale of eggs is no doubt due mainly to the fixing of a maximum price. the decrease in the sale of cheese has been accompanied by an increase in the stocks fromsix days' to eight days' supply, and is probably due to the holding back of sales inview of the reduced release of Government cheese announced for January. The percentage changes compared with the preceding four weeks, and with thecorresponding weeks a year ago are as follows : - Sales in Four Weeks ended 21st Dec. Stocks. The changes in stocks during the Christmas week have been unimportant exceptthat the stocks of cheese have declined by 2,000 tons and now stand at 22,400 tons or about nine weeks' supply. Stocks of meat declined 1,000 tons, but stocks of canned meat rose 900 tons; poultry and game declined 270 tons........... A substantial proportion of the bacon imports from America is being stored bythe Ministry the figures are as follows : -- Total quantity stored. STOCKS of the PRINCIPAL FOODS and FEEDING STUFFS in the UNITED KINGDOM. Tlio figures for wheat and flour include stocks in port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms ; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and iu mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks iu port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks iu possession of the Sugar Commission ; those for butter, margarine,lard, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, and in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses. The figures for tea, coffee, and cocoa are stocks remaining in bonded warehouses or entered to bewarehoused; and those for oilseeds and oilseed cake include stocks at ports and in the hands of millers,crushers, and cake manufacturers.Article.December 1st, 1918.November 1st, 1918.December 1st, 1917,Stocks in the United Kingdom including estimated Farm Stocks.Wheat (including flour)BarlevOatsBearsPeasMaize - - -Rice (including ground rice and rice flour)Grain Meals ....Butter - - -MargarineLard.Cheese - - - -Coudensed milk meat: Beef (chilled and frozen) Mutton (chilled and frozen) Bacon and Hams Poultry, Game, and Rabbits Other MeatFishTeaCoffeeCocoa.Oilseeds, &c.Oilseed Cake and Meal Tons.3,088,000 896,0002,953,000 193,000 96,000 lous.3,190,0001,154.0003,460,000 190,000 103,000 Tons.2,468,000 911,0002,563,000 124,000 46,000Stocks in the United Kingdom at Ports, Warehouses, &c. 37,000152,000 50,000381,000 24,000155,000 48,000414,000 33,000160,000 47,000212,000Stocks in the United Kingdom in Cold Stores and in Importers' and Wholesalers' Warehouses. 8,500 1,50033,60026,60043,00072,200.19,30059,500 4,70041,20024,80010,000 1,40031,50027,90049,10045,30020,10078,700 5,20037,20027,100 5,100 4,300 6,300 18,400*14,100 48,300 23,900 9,300 3,600 20,100 19,600Stocks in the United Kingdom, remaining in Bonded Warehouses, or entered to be Warehoused.Stocks in the United Kingdom at Ports and in the hands of Millers, Crushers, and Cake Manufacturers,217,500 87,200304,600107,000 * In manufacturers' hands only.NUMBER OF LIVE STOCK IN GREAT BRITAIN.--- December 1th, 1918(Estimated).$ October 4th, 1918 (Estimated).!?
